+AsapScience Sorry, I tried to watch this whole video, but I couldn't finish it. The whole time I was watching it, I kept thinking "What about redheads like me?" I know this is going to sound odd to the people whose hair is not naturally red, but everytime I go outside during the day, the sun does not feel "warm and inviting" to me as I've heard just about everyone around me claim it is for them. Instead, it causes an instantaneous, dull, constant PAIN that lasts until I've gone back inside. This is to say, I can literally FEEL the sun burning me before I've even developed an even close to visible sunburn. Also, the vitamin D thing, I would love to see a video regarding the science behind whether or not redheads actually NEED sunlight, because (I'm not sure if it's true but) I've heard from several sources, some of them science professors, who say that redheads have the unique ability of being able to manufacture our own vitamin D WITHOUT the sun as a result of our ancestors living in such sun-less climates. Basically, I'm asking you to make a video about redheads. Do redheads NEED the sun like everyone else? Or are we the exception? Also, what are some other facts about redheads, backed by science, that you can find? I'm sure I'm not the only redhead watching this channel who's curious about redhead-biology.

I work, browse the internet and play video games standing up sometimes. At first it's kind of tiring but as you get used to it you feel more energized, alert and engaged in what you're doing. And you feel better throughout the day as a result, too. Many businesses now allow their employees to use standing desks for this very reason.

This isn't about never going outside, this is about vitamin-deficiency; we can get Vitamin D from other sources like multi-vitamins.
And Seasonal Affective Disorder is NOT caused by Vitamin D deficiency, since Vitamin D is stored in your fat-cells and can stay there for YEARS. 
Rather, SAD is  a hibernation-like response to lower light-levels in order to conserve energy.when there's less food available and it's colder out; that's why it can be cured by  a few minutes of exposure to special sunlight-type lamps. 
Finally, of COURSE less-crowded environments are going to experience less fear and stress, people are only MEANT to live with about 500 other people so you'd know who to trust; meanwhile cities can pack thousands of people in a square mile.and you're afraid of everyone.
Finally, being indoors doesn't cause you to sit, more, and it's nothing a little exercise can't fix; in contrast, doing a lot of outdoor work causes the body to wear out prematurely.

2:16 how is it possible to control for "amount of physical activity" when the time spent sitting directly influences the amount of physical activity? 

For example, person A sits 5 hours a day (burning 50 calories) and exercises 1 hour a day (burning 100 calories). Person B stands 5 hours a day (burning 150 calories) and exercises 0 hours per day. 

If they truly "controlled for physical activity" then person A and person B would be in the same camp of amount of physical activity (burned same calories). After all, whether you're standing or sitting down is a part of "physical activity", with the former being more active than the latter. But did they really prove that people like person B live longer than people like person A?

I don't agree with the idea that you are naturally less stressed in natural vs urban environments. 
It's all about reference points.

For instance, many of us tend to grow up in human areas, while we are taught to view natural scenery as good and not associate with work, stress & crime which we are very familiar with.

On the other hand, for someone who has been fighting to survive outdoor in a survivalist manner, fighting everyday in order to live, they might associate a forest or jungle with stress, while viewing human landscape as peaceful & safe.

Correlation does not mean causation. Sitting time is correlated with mortality because only physically healthy people go for walks and practice sports. Thus, have less sitting time. It's not like sitting time is causing anything. Sitting time and mortality are both causes of the same thing - physical fitness.
And sure, exercise always makes better health. But not so much is required as I usually hear derived from this misinterpreted correlation.

"It does". Your backbone is made of vertebraes, to avoid friction, there's something called "discs" which are between each vertebrea. They are filled with water and act like an hydrolic suspension. Through the day, the discs will loose their water, they are working all day because we are in a vertical position.

When we go to sleep, we turn into an horizontal position, the discs retake their normal shape and refill themselves in water. So in fact, you're taller in the morning than at night.
